questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The thief was caught by the police.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'thief' receives the action. Structure: was + V3 (was caught) with 'by the police' indicates passive voice.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The children are playing football in the park.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'children' performs the action of playing. Present continuous active form.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The letter has been posted by her.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'letter' receives the action. Structure: has been + V3 (has been posted) indicates present perfect passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'Mother cooks delicious food every day.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'Mother' performs the action of cooking. Simple present active form.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The window was broken by the naughty boys.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'window' receives the action. Structure: was + V3 (was broken) with agent indicates passive voice.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'She will complete the project tomorrow.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'She' performs the action. Simple future active form (will + V1).

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The cake is being baked by my grandmother.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'cake' receives the action. Structure: is being + V3 indicates present continuous passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The teacher praised the students for their hard work.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'teacher' performs the action of praising. Simple past active form.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'All the cookies had been eaten before I arrived.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'cookies' receives the action. Structure: had been + V3 indicates past perfect passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The manager will announce the results tomorrow.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'manager' performs the action. Simple future active form.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The book must be returned to the library.'
questions.explanation: Modal passive structure: must + be + V3. The subject 'book' receives the action.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'She has written a beautiful poem.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'She' performs the action. Present perfect active form (has + V3).

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The news was being broadcast when the power went off.'
questions.explanation: Structure: was being + V3 indicates past continuous passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'We should help the poor.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'We' performs the action. Modal + V1 is active voice.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The criminal has been arrested by the police.'
questions.explanation: Structure: has been + V3 (has been arrested) indicates present perfect passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The mechanic is repairing my car.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'mechanic' performs the action. Present continuous active form.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The work will be finished by tomorrow.'
questions.explanation: Structure: will be + V3 (will be finished) indicates simple future passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The birds build nests in trees.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'birds' performs the action of building. Simple present active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The patient was being examined by the doctor.'
questions.explanation: Structure: was being + V3 indicates past continuous passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'They had completed the assignment before the deadline.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'They' performs the action. Past perfect active form.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'English is spoken all over the world.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'English' receives the action. Simple present passive (is + V3).

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The dog chased the cat.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'dog' performs the action of chasing. Simple past active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The road is being repaired.'
questions.explanation: Structure: is being + V3 indicates present continuous passive. Agent is omitted.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'My father bought a new car yesterday.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'father' performs the action of buying. Simple past active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The report will have been submitted by Friday.'
questions.explanation: Structure: will have been + V3 indicates future perfect passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'She can speak five languages.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'She' performs the action. Modal + V1 is active voice.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The match was won by our team.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'match' receives the action. Simple past passive (was + V3).

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The company manufactures electronic goods.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'company' performs the action. Simple present active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The injured were taken to the hospital.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'injured' receives the action. Simple past passive (were + V3).

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The children were singing songs.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'children' performs the action. Past continuous active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'Let the door be opened.'
questions.explanation: Imperative passive structure: Let + object + be + V3.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'Someone has stolen my wallet.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'Someone' performs the action. Present perfect active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The building was destroyed by the earthquake.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'building' receives the action. Simple past passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The students must complete the homework.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'students' performs the action. Modal + V1 is active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'A new school is being built in our locality.'
questions.explanation: Structure: is being + V3 indicates present continuous passive.

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The gardener is watering the plants.'
questions.answer: The plants are being watered by the gardener.
key_points: Present continuous: is watering → are being watered

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Someone has stolen my bicycle.'
key_points: Present perfect: has stolen → has been stolen
'By someone' can be omitted as agent is unknown

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The children will sing the national anthem.'
questions.answer: The national anthem will be sung by the children.
key_points: Simple future: will sing → will be sung

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Did the mechanic repair the car?'
questions.answer: Was the car repaired by the mechanic?

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The homework was completed by the students.'
key_points: Simple past passive → simple past active

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'English is spoken all over the world.'
questions.answer: People speak English all over the world.
key_points: When agent is missing, use general subject

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'My mother had prepared dinner before we arrived.'
questions.answer: Dinner had been prepared by my mother before we arrived.
key_points: Past perfect: had prepared → had been prepared

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The doctor can cure this disease.'
questions.answer: This disease can be cured by the doctor.
key_points: Modal verb passive: can cure → can be cured

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The window was broken by the naughty boys.'
questions.answer: The naughty boys broke the window.
key_points: Simple past passive → simple past active

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'They are building a new bridge across the river.'
questions.answer: A new bridge is being built across the river (by them).
key_points: Present continuous: are building → is being built

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The match was won by our team.'
key_points: Simple past passive → simple past active

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Who wrote this letter?'
questions.answer: By whom was this letter written?

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Nobody can answer this question.'
questions.answer: This question cannot be answered by anybody.

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The injured were taken to the hospital.'
questions.answer: Someone took the injured to the hospital. / They took the injured to the hospital.
key_points: Add general subject when agent is missing

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The committee will have finished the report by Friday.'
questions.answer: The report will have been finished by the committee by Friday.
key_points: Future perfect: will have finished → will have been finished

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Open the door.'
Change from passive voice to active voice: 'Let the work be done immediately.'
Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The police arrested the criminal.'
questions.answer: The criminal was arrested by the police.

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'She teaches us English.'
questions.answer: We are taught English by her. / English is taught to us by her.
key_points: With two objects, either can become subject

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The storm damaged the crops.'
questions.answer: The crops were damaged by the storm.

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The book has been read by many people.'
questions.answer: Many people have read the book.
key_points: Present perfect passive → present perfect active

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'They will announce the results next week.'
questions.answer: The results will be announced next week (by them).
key_points: Simple future: will announce → will be announced

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The boy was flying a kite.'
questions.answer: A kite was being flown by the boy.
key_points: Past continuous: was flying → was being flown

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The lesson is being explained by the teacher.'
questions.answer: The teacher is explaining the lesson.
key_points: Present continuous passive → present continuous active

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Mother has cooked delicious food.'
questions.answer: Delicious food has been cooked by Mother.
key_points: Present perfect: has cooked → has been cooked

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The manager will give you a promotion.'
questions.answer: You will be given a promotion by the manager. / A promotion will be given to you by the manager.
key_points: Either indirect or direct object can become subject

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The letter was being typed by the secretary.'
questions.answer: The secretary was typing the letter.
key_points: Past continuous passive → past continuous active

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'We must follow the rules.'
questions.answer: The rules must be followed by us.
key_points: Modal verb: must follow → must be followed

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Has she finished the work?'
questions.answer: Has the work been finished by her?

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The food should not be wasted.'
questions.answer: We should not waste the food. / One should not waste the food.
key_points: should not be wasted → should not waste

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The fire destroyed the building.'
questions.answer: The building was destroyed by the fire.

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Someone is following us.'
key_points: Present continuous: is following → are being followed

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The thief had been caught before the police arrived.'
questions.answer: Someone had caught the thief before the police arrived.
key_points: Past perfect passive → past perfect active

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Why did you break the glass?'
questions.answer: Why was the glass broken by you?

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'People believe that he is innocent.'
questions.answer: It is believed that he is innocent. / He is believed to be innocent.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'Rice is grown in many countries.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'Rice' receives the action. Simple present passive (is + V3).

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The artist is painting a beautiful picture.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'artist' performs the action. Present continuous active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The meeting has been postponed.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'meeting' receives the action. Present perfect passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'She gave me a beautiful gift.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'She' performs the action of giving. Simple past active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The noise could be heard from far away.'
questions.explanation: Modal passive: could + be + V3. The subject receives the action.

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The lion killed the deer.'
questions.answer: The deer was killed by the lion.

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'She is cooking dinner.'
questions.answer: Dinner is being cooked by her.
key_points: Present continuous: is cooking → is being cooked

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The tree was cut down by the woodcutter.'
questions.answer: The woodcutter cut down the tree.
key_points: Simple past passive → simple past active

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'They have not finished the project.'
questions.answer: The project has not been finished by them.
key_points: Negative present perfect: have not finished → has not been finished

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'When will you return the book?'
questions.answer: When will the book be returned by you?

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The letter may be sent tomorrow.'
questions.explanation: Modal passive: may + be + V3.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'They were watching the movie when I arrived.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'They' performs the action. Past continuous active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The car had been repaired before the journey.'
questions.explanation: Past perfect passive: had been + V3.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The farmer grows vegetables in his field.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'farmer' performs the action. Simple present active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'By whom was the window broken?'
questions.explanation: Interrogative passive with 'By whom'. Structure: was + V3.

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Do you know him?'
Change from active voice to passive voice: 'They elected him captain.'
questions.answer: He was elected captain by them.

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'A letter is being written by her.'
Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Please help me.'
questions.answer: You are requested to help me.
key_points: Polite request becomes 'You are requested to...'

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Do not pluck the flowers.'
questions.answer: Let the flowers not be plucked. / The flowers should not be plucked.
key_points: Do not → Let...not be / should not be

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'You are requested to maintain silence.'
questions.explanation: Structure 'are requested to' indicates passive transformation of a request.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The doctor has examined the patient.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'doctor' performs the action. Present perfect active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'Tea is liked by most Indians.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'Tea' receives the action. Simple present passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'She will have completed the course by June.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'She' performs the action. Future perfect active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'This book was written by Tagore.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'book' receives the action. Simple past passive.

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'Somebody told me the news.'
questions.answer: I was told the news. / The news was told to me.
key_points: Two objects - indirect (me) or direct (news) can become subject

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'People say that he is a genius.'
questions.answer: It is said that he is a genius. / He is said to be a genius.

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'The documents must be signed by the manager.'
questions.answer: The manager must sign the documents.

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'One should keep one's promise.'
Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The cat drank all the milk.'
questions.answer: All the milk was drunk by the cat.

questions.question: Change from passive voice to active voice: 'I was given a present by my uncle.'
questions.answer: My uncle gave me a present.
key_points: Simple past passive with two objects → active

questions.question: Change from active voice to passive voice: 'The watchman opens the gate every morning.'
questions.answer: The gate is opened by the watchman every morning.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'A song is being sung by the children.'
questions.explanation: Structure: is being + V3 indicates present continuous passive.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'He may not attend the meeting.'
questions.explanation: The subject 'He' performs the action. Modal + V1 is active.

questions.question: State whether the sentence is in 'active' or 'passive' voice: 'The work will have been completed by then.'
questions.explanation: Structure: will have been + V3 indicates future perfect passive.
